Award.AwardTitle: Investigations on Dark Matter and Dark Energy
Award.AbstractNarration: The identification of dark matter and the understanding of dark energy are among the major open questions in physics, astrophysics, and cosmology. The research outlined in this proposal addresses the question of the nature of dark matter in the following ways: (1) understanding if and how the annihilation of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs) affected the formation of the first stars in the universe; (2) connecting the mass and interaction properties of neutralino dark matter to the size of the smallest dark matter structures, which may be observable through gamma-ray emission; (3) computing the quantum radiative corrections necessary for a reliable evaluation of the density of multi-TeV neutralinos and their observable signals; (4) maintaining and upgrading the DarkSUSY code for neutralino dark matter calculations; (5) studying directional direct detection of WIMPs with the goal of extracting the maximum amount of information on the astrophysics of WIMPs; (6) examining the dark matter content of tidal streams in the Milky Way halo, with an eye on their possible detection. The broader educational component of this proposal is that the PI seeks to continue a very successful outreach program of public demonstrations on basic physics that has been taking place in collaboration with a local museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the currently outstanding problems of physics, astrophysics, and cosmology is the nature of the dark matter that comprises more than ninety percent of the matter in the universe. The idea of dark matter stems from measurements of the mass of galaxies and galaxy clusters and of the expansion rate of the universe. Over thirty years of diverse observations can be explained with the presence of a new form of matter that does not emit nor absorb light, aptly called the dark matter. While observations are telling where dark matter is and how much there is, we are still in the dark about what dark matter is.

The research under this award continues the exploration of ways to determine the nature of dark matter. Dark stars (i.e., stars powered by dark matter, a previous by the PI and collaborators) have continued to be explored from the particle physics and the astrophysics points of view, and for possibilities of detecting them in the cosmic microwave background or with the James Webb Space Telescope. The important technical question of channeling in dark matter searches using crystals has been thoroughly examined. Constraints have been placed on the idea that dark matter may be a scalar particle with mass below a hundredth of the proton's mass, using neutrinos to precisely determine the central temperature of the Sun. Searches for weakly interacting massive particles have been consistently analyzed and detection claims have been shown to be barely compatible with negative searches. Axions have been reexamined as dark matter candidates, leading to a revised value for their preferred mass. New short-range forces and special cases of supersymmetric particles have been considered in separate attempts to explain an observed excess of cosmic ray positrons as due to dark matter. New short-range forces have also been advocated for claims of having detected dark matter with a mass of a few times the proton mass. Other technical explorations of particle physics models for the dark matter complete the research framework.

Broader aspects of this award have been directed toward a successful program of bringing physics and astronomy to the public through actively-engaging demonstrations in museums, libraries, and schools: the Phun with Physics program. And a widely-used software package for the dark matter community, DarkSUSY, has been upgraded and maintained.
